4 of 4/ Also, the docs don't mention that Nginx needs execute permissions on Mastodon

So chmod +x /home/mastodon -R

Maybe @joinmastodon could clean up the docs a bit

Anyways excited to start exploring my own instance!

Hoping to be @jimcarroll@beingoblio.com

Because no point! https://t.co/ITzqLa81YJ

3 of 4/ Nginx will fail for the certbot process; you have to make sure that you are doing a certonly method. 

Why? The supplied /etc/nginx/sites-available/mastodon file will not allow nginx to start

So remove the 'enabled' setup before doing cert-only so that you can run nginx!

2 of 4/ I installed on Ubuntu 22.04 on a Vultr server. It would be helpful if @joinmastodon had some 'mininum specs.' The compile process required a 2gb mem machine. Knowing that in advance would have saved some grief.

1 of 4/ Decided if I was going to do Mastodon, I wanted to understand it by running my own instance.

I finally succeeded but the folks @JoinMastodon could clean up some things on their "Installing from Source" page.

30/ - It’s a pretty stunning list. Ask yourself – does this sound like anyone you know today?
29/ - a belief they will never fail – until they do
28/ - a tendency to blame others for failure – it’s ‘not their fault’
27/ - lower risk and thereby act accordingly
26/ - suffer from ‘risk perception bias’ – a belief that they can easily modify and
25/ - a belief that they will *do better* than anyone else
24/ - a belief that they know better than anyone else
23/ - overconfidence in their judgment
22/ - countless histories of not following the rules and getting away with it
21/ - excessive pride is driven by previous success
20/ - lacking in empathy, demonstrated by not caring for others
19/ - a belief that they are truly accurate in predicting the future
18/ - inability to work well with others
17/ - overt, excessive arrogance
16/ - a belief that they have a unique ‘magic touch'
15/ - exaggerated self-importance
14/ - a belief that nothing can go wrong
13/ - reality is impacted by excessive laudatory PR
12/ - lack of pushback by self-assembled sycophants
11/ - discouragement of free-thinking debate
10/ - dismissal of all criticism
9/ - a belief in all the praise that surrounds them
8/ - overconfidence – they believe can do no wrong

101/ Do it now
100/ Do it often
99/ Do more
98/ Do better
97/ Build your ideas, don't just think about them
96/ Find more heroes
95/ Channel frustration into more focused action
94/ Restart that thing that you abandoned
93/ Never presume that something is finished
92/ Master the art of learning, not hiding, from constructive criticism
91/ Be open - solicit feedback
90/ Share your gratitude
89/ Give back
88/ Don't let angry people bring you down
87/ Remember there is always a chance for a hole in one
86/ Motivate others with your enthusiasm
85/ Admit when you are wrong
84/ Avoid the dangerous drug of denial
83/ Fret less
82/ Play more
81/ Waste more time learning things completely unrelated to who you are
80/ Indulge your creativity
79/ Remember that innovation is for everyone, not the mission of a privileged few
78/ Find what you love, and build your life around it
77/ Remember that your imagination is your most powerful asset
76/ Avoid those who will try to destroy your optimism
75/ Ignore those who tell you your idea won't succeed
74/ Pursue bigger goals
73/ Act on your dreams
72/ Regularly interrupt your complacency
71/ Keep in mind that stupid is not a strategy
70/ Accept that change happens
69/ Don't try to fight the future - because the future always wins
68/ Remember that any particular day can suddenly turn out to be incredibly complicated and hard
67/ Never argue with false facts
66/ Pause 10 seconds before you send an angry tweet
65/ Be patient with difficult people
64/ Don't punish people for your mistakes
63/ Resist the energy that lies within your anger
62/ Remember it's ok to feel down sometimes - but work hard to chase the 'up'
61/ Remind yourself it could be worse
60/ Act faster to achieve more
59/ Keep in mind that committees are where great ideas go to die
58/ Move on from bad things faster
57/ Don't regret the things you haven't done - anticipate what you have yet to do
56/ Lighten your mood - avoid the heavy
55/ Remind yourself you don't need to love every waking moment - it's ok to get down
54/ Cultivate your compassion
53/ Work hard to avoid the trap of boredom
52/ Take more time to enjoy what you enjoy
51/ Regularly nurture your optimism - its fertilizer for your soul
50/ Enhance your gratitude every moment you can
49/ Make the best of the worst moments
48/ Quit quitting
47/ Avoid angry people
46/ Try new things - regularly
45/ Stop being surprised at surprises
44/ Don't be selfish - be magnanimous
43/ Consider that ignorance is a call for action,
42/ Don't always presume you are right - avoid being obstinate
41/ Spend every day tuning your roadmap for how you plan to live your life.
40/ Put in the work.
39/ Stop seeking an easy way out. There isn't one.
38/ Don't be first. Be better.
37/ Don't let uncertainty cloud your vision
36/ Stop trying to find the right way - just find a way
35/ Avoid fad-ism
34/ Never say "we tried that, it didn't work"
33/ Turn your lack of courage into enthusiasm
32/ Don't take on too many activities, take on too many ideas
31/ Use aggressive fear of change as a basic personal motivation
30/ Never think you've got too much information - drown yourself in ideas
29/ Don't allow yourself to go from feast to famine with knowledge
28/ Seek out interesting things - waste time with them
27/ Don't hide from problems - learn from them
26/ Create a culture in which it is okay to make mistakes, and unacceptable not to learn from them.
25/ Kill your aggressive indecision
24/ Stop making excuses, make actions
23/ Don't presume every dumb idea is a stupid idea - some of them are probably brilliant
22/ Stop focusing on regret for what you haven't done and look forward with enthusiasm to what you could still do
21/ Master the skill of mistake-based learning.
20/ Recognize that mistakes are a natural part of the process of success
19/ Stop saying it can't be done - just do it already!
18/ Don't feel bad about the mistakes you've made - view some of them as a pathway to success
17/ Find the thing that scares you the most. Conquer it
16/ Don't presume your business model will survive the next 5 years
15/ Just because it's not happening right now doesn't mean that it never will
14/ Stop trying old solutions to new problems
13/ Clinging to your past is probably the worst thing you can do right now
12/ Right now, it's pretty certain that someone out there is messing up your business model - and you aren't even aware of them.
11/ It's not what you know, it's what you don't know that matters
10/ If you aren't thinking fast enough, speed will get you
9/ It's the unknown and unforeseen that will get you every time
8/ Insanity is when you want something different but you are averse to undertaking the change
7/ If your success is based on what you did yesterday rather than what you will do tomorrow, redefine your idea of success
6/ If no one can remember the last time you did anything cool, you've got a bigger problem than you think
5/ Everyone has a different breaking point - make yours stronger
4/ If you seek the status quo, stop
3/ If a committee is killing your creativity, kill the committee
2/ If you don't know what comes next, learn more

Explaining the Premiums Paid for Large Acquisitions
Harvard Business Review
1/3/97

(These things never end well. CEO hubris. It's a thing)

3 of 4/ "The greater the CEO's confidence in his or her own abilities (as well as those of subordinates), the greater the benefits the CEO believes he or she can bring to an acquired entity and the higher the price paid"
2 of 4 "This represents a tendency to attribute organizational success to the CEO and for the CEO to deem that success as applicable to managing additional entities."

1 of 4/ "We have found that several sources of hubris have their own independent and additive effects on the premium the acquiror is willing to pay. First, the better the recent performance of the acquiring firm, the more that is paid for an acquisition."

12/ -  if you haven’t accelerated your knowledge asset capabilities, the skills that you have to take you into a new and different future will be lacking

14/ I could go on. The fact is, world-class innovators, do all these things and more. Learn that more at https://t.co/uV315s6XEu https://t.co/dFSHRYAWva
13/ They focus on extreme skills specialization, aware that their ability to find extremely unique skills will be crucial to future success
12/ They invest in experiential capital, knowing that every mistake they make by trying something new is an asset to be treasured – and allow their people to fail
11/ They’re aligned to scientific rapidity as a key strategy for future success – and find the unique niche skills to accomplish that
10/ They focus on collaborative innovation rather than narrow innovation – and form ‘fast teams’ to accomplish that
9/ They revisit plans with regularity, knowing the future is not cast in stone – and put in place agility and flexible structure
8/ They presume growth and opportunity, rather than stagnation and threat – and set that tone for their team
7/ They are prepared for a big market and industry transformation and know that success in the future is not guaranteed – and ensure they can realign their skill set to that reality
6/ They have redefined innovation to make it inclusive, rather than making it the domain of a small, elite group
5/ They focus on knowledge replenishment: they know the knowledge they have is going to go out of date quickly.
4/ They establish an “enabling” culture that encourages open thinking, rather than a “stifling” culture that glues the status quo into place.
3/ They permit self-organizing teams that abolish hierarchy
2/ Here's what I’ve seen from world-class innovators that let them build a structure that aligns with this faster future:

1/ “When it comes to the future, it’s the structure, not just the strategy, that matters!” – Futurist Jim Carroll

Or it can be put this way: “Those who structure for tomorrow will lead the opportunities of tomorrow!”

24/ It’s here, it’s everywhere, and it’s not going away. Accept it, and let it motivate you rather than detract you.
23/ ----> Embrace the uncertainty.<-------
22/ This too shall pass! Everything you do today might have a return tomorrow, even if we have no idea yet what that might be. Because – what’s the alternative?
21/ ----> Think longer term. <-------
20/ See ‘vague plan.’ If you had the planning wrong, adjust the plan. What should you be doing online a month from now? Heck, I don’t know. You’ll know when you get there!
19/ ----> Modify more. <-------

18/ There is no immediate return like there was in the past because complexity can obscure the win. But when they happen – oh, they are SO much better!
Collaborate more. See ‘learn as you go‘ above. The global hive mind is your new best friend. Learn how to harness its riches.
17/ ----> Keep the faith: don’t give up. <-------

16/ This is not about excellence. This is about achievement.
Work the criticism. When you get it wrong, take the lumps. Listen to the critics. Learn from what they tell you. Use it as an opportunity to do better.
15/ ----> Go for the small wins. <-------

14/ Don’t be scared. Learn from them. Repeat. For a long time, the mantra has been to fail often, fail early, and fail fast. While the idea is often rightfully criticized, there is now no doubt that speed has taken over our agenda, and we must respond accordingly.
13/ ----> Make mistakes. <-------

12/ ----> Keep your plan vague: don’t overdo it. <-------

The old world had us in long, luxurious planning cycles. That’s gone – both the time horizon and the certainty of the plan. Speed matters more than a plan, more so than ever before. It’s OK to figure things out as you go.
11/ Your goal should be to know WAY MORE today than you knew a month ago about things you were not aware of two months ago. My thirst for new knowledge is now at an all-time high.
10/ You are an expert at nothing in this new world and an amateur at everything. Just-in-time knowledge has long been my key skills watchword. It’s now a reality.
9/ ----> Learn as you go. <-------

5/ Every single organization is operating at a speed that was incomprehensible before the pandemic; while we spoke of the need for corporate agility before, our world now demands something much more.

102/ What was this post about? I scribble a lot of notes to myself. Every once in a while I collect them and dump them into a post.
101/ Do it now
100/ Do it often
99/ Do more
98/ Do better
97/ Build your ideas, don't just think about them
96/ Find more heroes
95/ Channel frustration into more focused action
94/ Restart that thing that you abandoned
93/ Never presume that something is finished
92/ Master the art of learning, not hiding, from constructive criticism
91/ Be open - solicit feedback
90/ Share your gratitude
89/ Give back
88/ Don't let angry people bring you down
87/ Remember there is always a chance for a hole in one
86/ Motivate others with your enthusiasm
85/ Admit when you are wrong
84/ Avoid the dangerous drug of denial
83/ Fret less
82/ Play more
81/ Waste more time learning things completely unrelated to who you are
80/ Indulge your creativity
79/ Remember that innovation is for everyone, not the mission of a privileged few
78/ Find what you love, and build your life around it
77/ Remember that your imagination is your most powerful asset
76/ Avoid those who will try to destroy your optimism
75/ Ignore those who tell you your idea won't succeed
74/ Pursue bigger goals
73/ Act on your dreams
72/ Regularly interrupt your complacency
71/ Keep in mind that stupid is not a strategy
70/ Accept that change happens
69/ Don't try to fight the future - because the future always wins
68/ Remember that any particular day can suddenly turn out to be incredibly complicated and hard
67/ Never argue with false facts
66/ Pause 10 seconds before you send an angry tweet
65/ Be patient with difficult people
64/ Don't punish people for your mistakes
63/ Resist the energy that lies within your anger
62/ Remember it's ok to feel down sometimes - but work hard to chase the 'up'
61/ Remind yourself it could be worse
60/ Act faster to achieve more
59/ Keep in mind that committees are where great ideas go to die
58/ Move on from bad things faster
57/ Don't regret the things you haven't done - anticipate what you have yet to do
56/ Lighten your mood - avoid the heavy
55/ Remind yourself you don't need to love every waking moment - it's ok to get down
54/ Cultivate your compassion
53/ Work hard to avoid the trap of boredom
52/ Take more time to enjoy what you enjoy
51/ Regularly nurture your optimism - its fertilizer for your soul
50/ Enhance your gratitude every moment you can
49/ Make the best of the worst moments
48/ Quit quitting
47/ Avoid angry people
46/ Try new things - regularly
45/ Stop being surprised at surprises
44/ Don't be selfish - be magnanimous
43/ Consider that ignorance is a call for action,
42/ Don't always presume you are right - avoid being obstinate
41/ Spend every day tuning your roadmap for how you plan to live your life.
40/ Put in the work.
39/ Stop seeking an easy way out. There isn't one.
38/ Don't be first. Be better.
37/ Don't let uncertainty cloud your vision
36/ Step trying to find the right way - just find a way
35/ Avoid fad-ism
34/ Never say "we tried that, it didn't work"
33/ Turn your lack of courage into enthusiasm
32/ Don't take on too many activities, take on too many ideas
31/ Use aggressive fear of change as a basic personal motivation
30/ Never think you've got too much information - drown yourself in ideas
29/ Don't allow yourself to go from feast to famine with knowledge
28/ Seek out interesting things - waste time with them
27/ Don't hide from problems - learn from them
26/ Create a culture in which it is okay to make mistakes, and unacceptable not to learn from them.
25/ Kill your aggressive indecision
24/ Stop making excuses, make actions
23/ Don't presume every dumb idea is a stupid idea - some of them are probably brilliant
22/ Stop focusing on regret for what you haven't done and look forward with enthusiasm to what you could still do
21/ Master the skill of mistake-based learning.
20/ Recognize that mistakes are a natural part of the process of success
19/ Stop saying it can't be done - just do it already!
18/ Don't feel bad about the mistakes you've made - view some of them as a pathway to success
17/ Find the thing that scares you the most. Conquer it
16/ Don't presume your business model will survive the next 5 years
15/ Just because it's not happening right now doesn't mean that it never will
14/ Stop trying old solutions to new problems
13/ Clinging to your past is probably the worst thing you can do right now
12/ Right now, it's pretty certain that someone out there is messing up your business model - and you aren't even aware of them.
11/ It's not what you know, it's what you don't know that matters
10/ If you aren't thinking fast enough, speed will get you
9/ It's the unknown and unforeseen that will get you every time
8/ Insanity is when you want something different but you are averse to undertaking the change
7/ If your success is based on what you did yesterday rather than what you will do tomorrow, redefine your idea of success
6/ If no one can remember the last time you did anything cool, you've got a bigger problem than you think
5/ Everyone has a different breaking point - make yours stronger
4/ If you seek the status quo, stop
3/ If a committee is killing your creativity, kill the committee
2/ If you don't know what comes next, learn more
1/ If you aren't scared of your competition, you should be.

19/ Lots of lessons to be learned here!

18/ They were busy trying to return to their old normal, instead of realizing that a different normal was unfolding. When you are trying to reach for an old goal and that goalpost is no longer there, you fail.
17/ Far too many organizations did not understand that. And so while they learned to operate at speed, they didn't really learn how to deal with resilience, exceptions, breakdowns.
16/ I think I was pretty bang on with the rest of the points on my list. I never had a sense that we would go back to where we were. Too much changed.

15/ I was wrong on the fast-vaccine issue, but if you look back at my 2017 post, "The Emerging Healthcare Reality Crisis," pretty right in predicting that there would be lots of folks who choose to disbelieve science. See it at https://t.co/R7cf1STRP6
14/ - you’ve fallen prey to the cult of delusion, the conspiracy of idiocy. Enough said. This might even make your future a lost cause.
13/ - ‘confirmation bias’ clouds your judgement. You prefer to believe those who tell you this will soon be over, and not to those who will tell you the truth
12/ - feeling helpless in face the of overwhelming change. Move faster along the 7 stages of economic grief!
11/ - a fear of confronting the truth. Your future will be pretty ugly, unless you start working at a furious pace RIGHT now to reinvent it
10/ - too much optimism for the speed of return to ‘normal.‘ It’s going to be a long, tortuous path out of this ‘thing’
9/ - an inability to comprehend what has actually changed. You need better insight – the changes occurring are profound

8/ - not understanding that everything has changed. It has. In massive ways.
not *accepting* that everything has changed. It has, forever.
7/ - a feeling of invincibility that drives inaction – that your business model, structure of other attributes will survive. Without drastic action, it probably won’t.
6/ - accepting our new reality seems like an admission of defeat. It’s not. It’s a foundation for action.
5/ - letting your ‘desire’ get in front of your ‘reality’ : you think the virus will soon be quashed or that a vaccine is imminent. It won’t be, and there won’t be.
4/ - a belief that we will soon get ‘back to normal’. We won’t.

42/ Learn more. Visit https://t.co/BbzU32oGvd
41/ a percentage of annual renumeration is based upon achievement of explicitly defined innovation goals
40/ the word “innovation” is found in most job descriptions as a primary area of responsibility
39/ people know that in addition to R&D, innovation is also about ideas about to “run the business better, grow the business and transform the business”
38/ rather than stating “it can’t be done,” people ask, “how could we do this?”
37/ there are creative champions throughout the organization — people who thrive on thinking about how to do things differently ideas get approval and endorsement
36/ there are many, many leaders who encourage innovative thinking, rather than managers who run a bureacracy
35/ success and failure are championed
34/ subversion is a virtue
33/ ideas flow freely throughout the organization

32/ WHAT SHOULD YOU DO ABOUT IT? Change your culture – adopt the mindset of innovation heroes!

In these organizations:
31/ “Don’t rock the boat”
30/ “Rules won’t allow it”
29/ “Why should I care?”
28/ “The boss won’t go for it” (5 bonus points)
27/ "I didn’t know that”
26/ “I don’t think I can”
25/ “I don’t know how”
24/ “It’s too risky” (3 bonus points)
23/ “It’s against tradition”
22/ “You can’t do that”
21/ “That’s not my problem”
20/ “That’s the dumbest thing I ever heard”
19/ “It won’t work”
18/ “We’ve always done it this way” (3 bonus points)
17/ 15 or more, and you might as well close up shop'
16/ Score 10 or more, and you are innovation dead.
15/ Score one point each time a phrase is used, plus bonus points as indicated. Score more than 5, and you’ve got an organization that is innovation-adverse.
14/ Print the list below, and take it into your next meeting.

13/ THE LIST OF INNOVATION KILLERS

Are you dying from organizational sclerosis? Find out!
12/ After any type of surprise — product, market, industry or organizational change — everyone sits back and asks, “wow, where did that come from?”
11/ There are lots of baby boomers about, and few people younger than 25
10/ The organization is focused more on process than success
9/ People have convinced themselves that competing on price is normal
8/ People think innovation is about R&D
7/ No one can remember the last time anyone did anything really cool
6/ The phrase, “you can’t do that because we’ve always done it this way” is used for every new idea
5/ Innovation is the privileged practice of a special group
4/ Someone who identifies a problem is shunned
3/ People laugh at new ideas
2/ Read this list. Is this your organization?

55/ The fact is that every organization should be able to develop innovation as a core virtue. If they aren’t doing that, they certainly won’t survive the rapid rate of change that envelops us today.

54/ The word “innovation” is found in most job descriptions as a primary area of responsibility, and a percentage of annual remuneration is based on achievement of explicitly defined innovation goals.
53/ People know that in addition to R&D, innovation is also about ideas for how to run the business better, grow the business, and transform the business.
52/ Rather than stating, “It can’t be done,” people ask, “How could we do this?”
51/ Ideas get approval and endorsement.
50/ There are creative champions throughout the organization – people who thrive on thinking about how to do things differently.
49/ There are many leaders who encourage innovative thinking – not just managers who run a bureaucracy.
48/ Success and failure are championed.
47/ Subversion is a virtue.
46/ Ideas flow freely throughout the organization.
45/ So how do innovative organizations differ? In these organizations:

44/ Here's the thing 

Innovative companies act differently
43/ After any type of surprise — product, market, industry, or organizational change — everyone sits back and asks, “Wow, where did that come from?”
42/ There are lots of Baby Boomers around, and few people younger than 25.
41/ The organization is focused more on process than success.
40/ People have convinced themselves that competing on price is normal.
39/ People think innovation is about R&D.
38/ No one can remember the last time anyone did anything really cool.
37/ The phrase, “You can’t do that because we’ve always done it this way” is used for every new idea.
35/ Someone who identifies a problem is shunned.
34/ People laugh at new ideas.
33/ Now try this - take the test of 10 Signs that You’ve Got an Innovation Dysfunction
32/ “Why should I care?” (10 bonus points)
31/ “The boss won’t go for it.” (5 bonus points)
30/ “I didn’t know that.”
29/ “I don’t think I can.”
28/ “I don’t know how.”
27/ “You can’t do that.”
26/ “That’s not my problem.”
25/ “That’s the dumbest thing I ever heard.”
24/ “It won’t work.”
23/ “We’ve always done it this way.” (3 bonus points)
22/ Score 10 or more, and you are innovation-dead. If you get 15 or more, you might as well close up shop.
21/ If your total is more than 5, you’ve got an organization that is innovation-averse.

20/ Are you in an innovation rut?

Find out!

Take the list below to your next meeting. Score one point each time a phrase is used, plus bonus points as indicated.

19/ And there are certainly more attitudes that help destroy innovative thinking. 

What are the other attitudes and ways of thinking that manage to shut down organizational idea machines?
18/ Your goal is ensuring that any decision is free of risk, unlikely to fail, and in retrospect will be carefully and fully documented.

17/ Study Things to Death. Don’t let any uncertainty creep into your decision-making process. Make sure that if you are to do anything, that you’ve spent sufficient time and effort to understand all the variables.
16/ Be Narrow. Keep a very tiny view of the future. You can’t succeed with any big wins, because there aren’t going to be any dramatic surprises in the future. Think small. Act accordingly.
15/ Glorify Process. Make sure that everything is filled out in triplicate; be sure process slows down any radical ideas. It’s more important to do things perfectly than to make mistakes.

14/ Be Cautious. Don’t make any bold, aggressive moves. Just take things slowly, one step at a time. If you move too fast, things are likely to go wrong. Let complacency settle in like a warm blanket.
12/ Presume the abscence of change. Everything will look the same 10 years from now, so just keep everyone focused on doing the same old thing!

11/ Banish Fear. Make sure that everyone thinks that everything is going to be all right. You don’t have to deal with potential business market disruption, new competitors, significant industry transformation, or the impact of globalization.
10/ They’ll just keep doing what they’ve always done.

9/ Let Innovators Work in Secret. You want to make sure that the concept of innovation remains some deep, mysterious process that not everyone can participate in. That will help to ensure that most of your team doesn’t pursue any type of fresh new thinking.
8/ Hide Failure. If anyone tries something new and doesn’t succeed, make sure that no one else sees it. You don’t want to set a message that it is important to take risks.
7/ Defer Decisions. It’s easier to wait than to make any bold, aggressive moves. Uncertainty is a virtue; indecision is an asset.
6/ Form a Committee. An absolute surefire way of shutting down ideas! The herd mentality takes over, and activity sclerosis soon sets in.
5/ Here are some points to consider to find out if your company is on the way to killing innovation.

4/ As I dig into the culture and attitude of a client through interviews with the CEO and other team members, I’m always mystified to find that some organizations just seem to do everything they can to shut down new ideas.

2/ You know that you are failing. Ideas are being lost, opportunities are being squandered, initiative is in a rut.

How do you know? Because you KNOW that your organization has a culture that is killing creativity.

38/ "Resilience and Agility: The New Critical Post Pandemic Leadership Strategies"

https://t.co/ESQT1NygzS
37/ Agility and resilience mean that you must now have in place a flexible, rolling, evolving strategy. There is no time to strategize at a slow speed when the world is fast.
36/ Agility and resilience? It also involves evolving your strategy faster – long gone are the days of the 2, 3, or even 5-year plan.
35/ - regularly identifying vulnerabilities and weak spots - and fixing that1
34/ - presuming that you move slower than everyone else – and fixing it
33/ - stopping with the insufficient investment
32/ - presuming a complex trajectory for what comes next.
31/ - challenging your peers more
30/ - do more horizon scanning with an effective trends radar
29/ - accepting VUCA as a constant – and stop chasing ‘normal,  because there isn’t any
28/ - accelerating scenario analysis – alternative futures are your future
27/ - moving from actions based on ‘weeks and months to ‘days and hours’
26/ - groups that challenge complacency
25/ - leaders that stop discounting the outliers
24/ - enabling insight at every level
23/ - a mindset that is relentless on redundancy – examining every point of weakness
22/ - a team that stops taking things for granted
21/ - thinking long term as to how you structure for faster future change
20/ - a focus that challenges process – quick runs, small orders
19/ - the ability to act in the presence of imperfect data
18/ - accelerated decision making
17/ - a mindset that cuts through organizational sclerosis
16/ - a culture that embraces speed of action as a key success factor
15/ - a structure that can reorganize quickly – the formation of fast teams is critical
14/ - the ability to spot new opportunities amidst the volatility
13/ - the ability to readjust goals to meet new realities
12/ - the ability to avoid the distraction of clarity – because there really isn’t any
11/ - real-time feedback loops that drive your (re)actions
10/ - flexible policies that shift in real-time
9/ - strategic nimbleness to respond faster to fast-moving events

8/ What is agility? It's the ability to shift mindsets and actions rapidly according to fast-moving circumstances. I've recently concluded a research project to take a look at the elements of agility and resilience:

7/ What do you need to achieve resilience? Succesful, agile organizations move faster – decisions, product development, time to market, and an attitude that future business survival now depends on that resilience.

6/ ...]I've gone so far as to suggest that organizations should now consider putting in place a "Chief Resilience Officer" - someone responsible for steering the organization through an unprecedented level of volatility, complexity, uncertainty, and ambiguity. https://t.co/7WhyoZvrW3

5/ Resilience? It's the ability to bounce back from VUCA - what has become known as an unprecedented level of volatility, complexity, uncertainty, and ambiguity. How important is it? Post-pandemic, it's critical, because levels of VUCA have accelerated through the roof! [
4/ …levels of volatility!

3/ If there is one lesson that organizations have learned through the pandemic, it's that their future survival is now heavily dependent upon the resilience they've put in place - and that resilience demands a new level of agility within their leadership team to respond to new…

31/ Over and out. Some responses go to > /dev/null.
30/ It’s a challenging world. Sometimes, it’s best that we keep our opinions to ourselves.
29/ And so as I think these things, I actually manage to avoid posting a lot of my reactive instinct.
28/ What impact will the post have on the work I do as a futurist?
27/ Does it make me look like a flaming idiot?
26/ What purpose would it serve other than letting me let off some steam?
25/ How does this actually affect my personal brand?
24/ What harm might it do?
23/ What good will it actually do me?
22/ Might it be more harm than good?
21/ Does anyone actually care?
20/ Will others actually learn anything from what I post?
19/ Have I really thought about how I should pause and think before I post something?
18/ What might what I post today look like five years from now?
17/ What is the actual purpose other than letting me manage my emotions?
16/ What is the likelihood that what I post might come back to haunt me?
15/ Is this something I would actually say in a room full of people I don’t know?
14/ Should I find some other way to deal with my frustration?
13/ Could the post do me damage?
12/ And so, I’ve come to think about the elements of action behind what I call my Social Media Serenity Prayer action plan:

11/ But given how volatile the Covid exit is likely to be, I’ve been doubling down on my effort to avoid posting, desperately trying to remind myself there is no upside than a momentary moment of relief.

10/ I’ve come to the point that I have no desire to engage, debate, negotiate or tolerate many of the views which now permeate our world. There is no upside. And I will admit I haven’t done a great job at managing my online presence over the years.
9/ I sometimes find it necessary to put some people on notice as to where I stand – and so for a long time, I’ve had this graph pinned to the top of my Twitter profile. https://t.co/gStRpbnrnE

8/ And often, to my credit, I don’t. Antixaxxer and vaccines? For a long time, I’ve wanted to post this picture to express my opinion: but I continually try to hold myself back from doing so. So I’ll just post it here and leave it at that. https://t.co/NTulaVipQJ

7/ But at each and every moment that I consume media, I often find myself bubbling with rage, consumed with my incredulity, struggling with my disbelief with what I see. I want to lash out, respond, and try to set things straight.
6/ (My sons and their fiances don’t think I should go near TiktTok, and I faced a similar edict with Snapchat.) I share insight on trends, innovation, creativity, things that capture my mind.
5/ Given what I do, I obviously have a social media presence – I’m on Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, Substack, Instagram.
4/ That’s why I try to work hard to keep my opinions to myself. As a futurist, I’m on the side of facts, in a world in which for many people, facts don’t matter – agendas do.

3/ Add in a dose of extremism, a sprinkling of madness and delusion, and a mixture of manipulation, and you’ve got a recipe for disaster. I don’t have high expectations at times – if it’s bad now we are likely to see a lot worse.

2/ The long exit from Covid amidst the incredibly poisoned societal atmosphere we now live within is going to be made much worse in the months to come, particularly as emotions run to an all-time high of volatility.

1/ The Social Media Serenity Prayer: 

“Grant me the maturity to understand the things I should not post, the insight to share the things I should, and the wisdom to quickly know the difference!” – Futurist Jim Carroll https://t.co/2VAbPucixs

105/ '101 Things We Know About Our Future' - An Esoteric List of Things That are Happening Now and Next!

It's at https://t.co/fRQwcDdx57

104/ Like I said: My mind all too often races with ideas; I think too much. The busy activities in my head lead me to regularly scribble down lots of thoughts about the world around me. 

I put a bunch into a list in a blog post..
103/ Fifty years out, people will still write lists of '101 things' because it provides a nice structure for creative thinking
102/ We will still be talking about how committees are evil well into the future - because stupid companies will still form committees
101/ Right not, there is a company that does not yet exist that will build a product not yet conceived, using material snot yet invented, with a methodology yet to be discovered.
100/ 50% of Wikipedia will be useless within 10 years because of 'link-rot'
99/ We will have figured out how to stop light in its tracks, which will have big implications for the future of all computer and chip technology
98/ One day, you'll wonder whatever happened to the idea of 'change management workshops
97/ The world of science will have taken us from 19 million known chemical substances today to 5 billion by 2100 - and this will lead to the birth of countless new billion-dollar industries
96/ In the future, the idea of a 'lighter than air' plane will not seem ridiculous.
95/ Most car dealers don't yet accept the inevitability of the demise of their business model
94/ Every single device that you use day today will be a featured piece in a museum in less than 25 years
93/ What we did for heart health in the 20th century, we did for brain health in the future
92/ Many of the trucks in the industrialized world today will be driven by virtual drivers on the other side of the world tomorrow
91/ 50% to 80% of the revenue that a company will generate by 2030 will come from a product or service that does not yet exist today
90/ Someone will figure out how you can spend an actual hour inside the very mind of your pet, thinking and seeing the world exactly as they do
89/ We will soon be growing human body parts in labs for use in many major surgical procedures
87/ We'll find that the hyped 'metaverse' didn't happen with avatars, but did with heads-up displays and similar technologies
86/ Human longevity in industrialized nations will undergo the first significant decline, dropping an average of 10 years, mostly with those who think science is not a thing
85/ You'll have a custom 3D food printer in your home as you become a part of the world of real-time, customizable food programming
84/ Some of the most respected democracies in the world will go full-fascist, leading to really challenging political realities
83/ Most major shopping malls of today won't fulfill that function tomorrow - they'll be something else altogether. We don't yet know what.
82/ The TV show the Jetsons will soon seem like it too is from the olden days
81/ Knee replacements will be grown at a bio-tissue farm, with customization based upon your specific DNA.
80/ Many crypto-currencies will become viewed much like tobacco, due to their destructive environmental impact
79/ Vision care will transition from the prescribing of eyeglasses to the basic procedure of preparing an implant of bionic eyes
78/ There is a child alive today who will receive the first cranial brain implant
77/ The volume of medical knowledge will have doubled by the time you re-read this post 78 days from now
76/ We won’t find it unusual at all to know that a child in the future might actually meet their great-great-great-greet-great-great-great-grandparent.
75/ Personal health concierges will be one of the fastest-growing career professions
74/ Likewise, one of the most important technologies in your life in ten years does not yet exist
73/ The newest trillion-dollar company that will be common in 2035 came from a product that didn't exist at the moment you read this
72/ By 2030, most actors have mostly become irrelevant – instead, avatars and deep-fake personalities will be purchased off the shelf, ready to be turned into the next great performance.

71/ Much like you might have a domain name or email address today, tomorrow you'll have your very own light spectrum on the infinite fiber-optic Internet, which will be reserved solely for your encrypted use on global optical networks
70/ Your self-driving car will 'talk' to a lot of the other self-driving cars around it in order to figure out where it is going and how to safely get there
69/ Most of your clothing will be smart, connected, aware - helping you with fitness, health, and safety
67/ Your car will have credit card capability embedded into the dashboard, in order to streamline drive-through and curbside pickup interactions

66/ The arrival of a faster future means the arrival of new insurance risk - and insurance companies will have to ensure for forms of risk that don't even yet exist, not even knowing what they are insuring for!
65/ The cost and complexity of car maintenance will have collapsed with the arrival of electric vehicles because there is really nothing to maintain

64/ A 'next billion-dollar industry' will be fully integrated home microgrids - with renewable energy (solar/wind), batteries for storage, tech to direct it directly into your car, all managed through a thermostat like a device
63/ Human brain augmentation technology will become a mainstream industry within the decade
61/ 40% of the big car makers of today won't exist by 2030, because they weren't able to make the shift to technology-focused electric vehicle technology
60/ One day, Apple will be delisted - every company eventually becomes irrelevant
59/ We're quickly moving from a world of computer code written by humans - to code-written-by-code-and-data
57/ The volume of known medical knowledge is increasing 48% annually, going from 153 exabytes in 2013 to 2,514 exabytes in 2020
56/ Rather than megabits and terabits, you'll be talking about yottabits. Hint: look it up
55/ We'll one day use 3D skin printing technology to deal with medical burns and other complex issues
54/ Real-time analytical predictive insurance underwriting will be the only actuarial insurance model in the not-too-distant future
53/ Most new homes will have driveway drone pads with an automatic storage locker as a standard feature
52/ Most of the cost of equipment in every industry will be within the software and the chips - and not within the other hardware
51/ Much of what you know today is already obsolete - you just don't know it yet
50/ Technology oriented seniors community care is a 'next big thing' - and will come just in time to deal with a massive flood of Alzheimer's' patients
49/ The acceleration gap between the speed of change and our ability to deal with it is big -- and getting bigger
48/ We'll probably soon have little robotic micro-drones regularly tending crops in agriculture
47/ Most regulatory bodies will continue to act slowly in a fast-paced world - and the disconnect of today will have bigger implications tomorrow
46/ In the future, you'll be able to buy a DNA sequencing machine at Dollar General. We don't yet know why.
45/ One day, the road on which you drive will automatically charge your electric car
44/ It's pretty likely that the US will follow the trajectory of the Roman Empire as its democracy goes into its death spiral
43/ Norway will hit 100% electric vehicles by 2025, and other nations will soon follow
42/ Urban farming within the 35 megacities of the future 20+ million people will change our entire concept of agriculture
41/ Half of the knowledge we get in the first year of university or college is obsolete, or out of date, by the time we graduate
40/ There is someone in a garage at this very moment with a really great idea that will become a billion-dollar company
39/ Your car dashboard of today will be obsolete in but 18 months, just like your smartphone
38/ One of the biggest energy opportunities in the next decade is to be found in an integrated home-energy wind/solar/battery/thermostat/iOT integrated system.
37/ Bionic, artificial eye implants will soon bring eyesight to the blind
36/ Your business model won't last next 10 years
35/ Most kids today will work in a job or career that does not yet exist
34/ You might one day golf with a personalized drone flying overhead, filming your round
33/ Just-in-time insurance will dominate the industry within a decade
32/ There are a lot of things you will use in 10 years that have not yet been invented.
31/ In the near future, you're going to eat "who you are", with daily food plans based on your personal DNA profile
30/ We're moving to a world of 24-hour farming - autonomy means that we no longer have to farm only when the sun is up
29/ Manufacturing is no longer about mass production, it's about mass customization
28/ Batteries are at the heart of most significant future trends
27/ We're quickly moving from 'learning how to drive to 'learning how to supervise a car'
26/ Baseball bats, golf clubs, and footballs will have spatial connectivity technology as a built-in feature - providing for a new era of sports and exercise feedback
25/ Insurance is moving from looking at the past performance of something to looking at real-time indicators from that thing
24/ Car companies don't know how to innovate at the speed of Silicon Valley. This is a BIG problem - for them
23/ We will soon have windows most everywhere that generate solar electricity, simply by being windows
22/ The concept of data-transmitting crops is a marvelous thing - and we'll see it in our lifetime
21/ Right now, someone has the perfect idea in mind to put your business model into a death spiral - and you might not notice till it is too late
19/ Machines are starting to think on their own a bit more. We don't yet know what this means.
18/ Change-resistant baby boomers are starting to leave the economy, making things even faster than they are
17/ There will soon be a lot of weed-zapping robots on farms, along with tiny robotic pollinating insects
16/ We're moving from a world in which we fix people after they're sick - to one in which we know what they are going to become sick with and act accordingly
15/ The next generation has no attention span whatsoever: and this has big implications for everything!
14/ The fact that there are 'fitbits for cows' is a trend that is helping to accelerate battery storage technology
13/ Most major companies will be at risk of failure through computer security hacking issues - until security becomes a Board of Directors responsibility
12/ You are surrounded by modern things right now that will become 'things from the olden days' during your lifetime
11/ We'll never go back to the world of in-person retail shopping like it was before Covid
10/ Africa is the next big economic powerhouse
9/ Connected pharmaceuticals will one day soon report on how well they are working inside your body
8/ Constant bio-connectivity body monitoring, such as done through your mobile device, will forever transform healthcare
7/ Solar power generation is growing faster than any other form of energy
6/ Oil is over. It's a sunset industry in decline as renewables come to dominate all future spending
5/ Here we do. 1/ We're obviously shifting from driving cars based on gas and internal combustion engines to those based on batteries and electric - and it will happen faster than you think
4/ Some are obvious, some are not so obvious. Let me know what other ones you think about. Contact me.
3/ Overall, as a futurist, it's a remarkable time to be alive - and with that in mind, here's a list that I've accumulated as to '101 things we know about our future.'

15/ What you are going to do right now is start to figure out why your future is in doubt - and formulate a plant to deal with it. You do that by starting here: . https://t.co/F6jE5BvmnG
14/ It’s going to happen to you too. So — what are you going to do about it?
13/ Examples of this type of disruption are occurring all around us right now.
12/ The result will be dramatic change :its likely that your current business model will not even survive: and your company might not as well!
11/ Most likely, you’ll discount the importance of their innovation, until it is much too late.
10/ Their business model will carry an undeniable ‘coolness factor’ that you can’t simply match.
9/ They’ll use this technology in such a way they’ll come out of left field with a business model idea that you’ve never even thought of before.
8/ The fundamental change to your business model driven by this younger generation will be the result of digital, smart, intelligent, location-oriented technology.
7/ Those that do mess up your business model are quite likely to be younger than you; for many folks, age provides for complacency.
6/ The result is that 10 years out (or less), your business model will look nothing like it does today.
5/ They’ll probably do this sooner than you think they will.
4/ If you aren’t busy thinking about to disrupt your business model, they most certainly will.
3/ Right now, there are probably a bunch of really smart people figuring out to disrupt your business model
2/ That’s because the rate of business model change is accelerating in every single industry. Here’s why:

1/ Give it a few years.

You won’t even recognize the industry you are operating in. And chances are, your company and the business model you operate in will be dead. 

Unless you change.

9/ Infrastructure? A while ago, I hit my virtual broadcast studio  to put it in the context of the 19th-century railroad system, the Eisenhower Interstate Highway system, and our 21st-century realities of renewables, electric vehicles, and hyperconnectivity. https://t.co/vUM99xFNFO
8/ Here’s a bit of a hint of what I’ve covered on stage on this trend in the last while. https://t.co/wLRUtLremo

7/ Here's the thing - the road you drive on and the bridge that you cross are also becoming intelligent, connected, aware and data-gathering. The impact everywhere is significant: everyone from construction companies to architectural design firms will be impacted.
6/ Imagine if they become part of the process of enhancing autonomy.

5/ But in this era in which everyone is paying attention to the self-driving vehicle trend, few are watching an equally significant development : the era of intelligent infrastructure. Streetlights are part of that reality.
4/ IMHO, Intelligent infrastructure is the Rodney Dangerfield of the age of autonomy, and doesn’t get any respect.

19/ “Start small” implies that you should be on board with any particular trend, despite the potential immaturity it might have, because you want to make sure that you understand it, have experience with it, know how to work with it – and are ready to go when it “goes supernova!”
18/ That’s why my mantra to “think big, start small, scale fast” gives a key shoutout to timing.
17/ And then, all of a sudden, it can ‘go supernova’, explode in importance and significance – and suddenly, be everywhere!
16/ Any particular trend can bubble along for a time, seemingly inconsequential and of little impact.

15/ The timing issue?

As Kevin Kelly, the founder of Wired noted, “the future happens slowly, and then, all at once.”
14/ But inevitably, both the expectations, idea and capabilities mature, and the trend becomes a key component for innovation and so much more.
13/ That is followed by the inevitable collapse of enthusiasm as people realize that it takes a lot of time and effort to implement the future, and determine the opportunity that comes from it.
12/ Timing? Any new technology, trend or idea goes along a curve – it appears, then hits the time of excessive hype and expectations.

29/ See the original post at: https://t.co/befnufHmH9
27/ In an era of fast change, organizations must be relentlessly innovative, and that requires drawing on the skills and creativity of everyone

26/ TEN -> It’s more diverse than ever!

Thriving in the future has a leadership that involves everyone involved in innovation.

No idea is too dumb, no opportunity is too small.

25/ Rapid prototyping, 3D printing and the maker community mean that a product can go from conception to reality in a matter of weeks – if not days.

We live in the era of the rapid idea-cycle.

24/ NINE -> It has a huge instantaneity

The average consumer scans 12 feet of shelf space per second. Most news becomes old hat within 36 hours of emerging.

23/ Gen-Connect — today’s 35 and under — will never think of change management issue.

They just change.

22/ EIGHT -> It involves a huge adaptability gap

Earlier generations — boomers — have had participated in countless “change management workshops,” reflecting the reality that many of them have long struggled with change.
21/ With rapid change, everyone in an organization must innovate. It’s no longer a world of “innovation elitists” who seem to believe that only special people can “do” innovation.

20/ Every industry is witnessing similar levels of disruption and acceleration. Complacency is a dangerous thing, particular when every organization is faced with constant, relentless external innovation from unexpected competitors.

It involves innovation inclusivity

19/ SEVEN -> It’s bigger than you think

At one time, people who spoke about an era in which Silicon Valley would become the new centre of the automotive universe were laughed at. And yet today, with self-driving cars and other efforts, it’s not a joke anymore.
18/ Real innovators invest in every new idea, uncertain as to the return of timing, knowing that one day their investment will eventually pay off.

17/ SIX -> It comes from experiential capital

With a fast future, you must learn and relearn.

Corporate equity isn’t just money: it’s the cumulative experience and knowledge of the team.
16/ Innovators are redefining the concept, making it collaborative and cooperative.

15/ FIVE -> It involves partnership

Old business models involved asking, “what can we do to run our business better?”

The new business model is this: “What can we do to run our customers, suppliers and partners business better?”
14/ Before you know, they’ve reinvented you, whether you like it or not.

13/ FOUR -> It’s being defined by renegades and rebels

Increasingly, the future of many an industry is being defined by industry expatriates. When a real innovator can’t innovate within a company, they step outside, form a startup, and spark massive industry change on their own.

11/ THREE -> It involves intensity

80% of the revenue from the typical video game is earned within 4 to 5 days of release. That’s becoming the norm in many industries — although not in days, but perhaps months.
10/ If you want to understand what comes next, study Gartner’s concept of “hype-cycles” – it puts into perspective the whole issues of timing.

9/ TWO -> It hits you most when you don’t expect it.

Every organization must deal with two realities: the rapid emergence of new technologies, and the sudden adoption of new ideas.

8/ There are furious rates of new scientific discovery.

Time is being compressed.

7/ ONE -> It’s incredibly fast

Product life cycles are collapsing.

It’s said that half of what students learn in their freshman year about science and technology is obsolete or revised by their senior year.
6/ To thrive, you need to understand the realities of today’s future.

5/ Here’s a simple reality: Innovation is all about adapting to the future — and if the future is coming at you faster, then you need to innovate faster.

Given that, innovation shouldn’t be about trying to survive the future — it should be about thriving.

4/ I will often tells the story of a senior executive at one client who put this into perspective, “….entities are engaged in survival tactics because they don’t know what to do next ….”

Is that you? Are you simply trying to survive, not thrive?
3/ With such change, there’s a lot of uncertainty within many industries as to what to do next.
2/ The rate of change — whether with business models, product life cycles, the rapid emergence of new competitors, business model disruption, skills and knowledge and more! — is speeding up.

What I predicted back in April on hesitancy. I was bang-on:

"It’s pretty obvious that the ability to return to where we were is being held back by those who refuse to accept what it will take to get there!” 

https://t.co/2o66cCxX8A
59/ The full original post is at: https://t.co/Gakudddbld
58/ Except, the implications for companies, economies, and people are far, far worse.
57/ I could go on; I’ll build up this list over time. It’s sort of like my Innovation Killers theme, which is worth a look.
56/ Their rage blinds them to the world (hint: look up “coal rollers”)
55/ Denial about the eventual emergence of the trend
54/ Clinging to an old trend because the alternative, the real future trend is too painful to contemplate
53/ Clinging to an old trend that no longer exists
52/ Clinging to an old trend that is no longer relevant
51/ The speed challenge – they are stuck in the slow lane in a fast world
50/ -the reality dodge (I don’t like the existing and future reality, so I’ll just make up my own!)
49/ The incumbency dodge (‘when things are great, they’ll always be great!’)
48/ An inability to accept global change (‘we’re the greatest and will always be the greatest!’)
47/ They have job skills that are outdated and don’t line up to existing realities but are unwilling to upgrade
46/ A belief that what exists today will exist tomorrow. (i.e. cars will always be based on carbon!)
45/ The future conflicts with their desire for things to stay the same – so they deny it (i.e. renewables, electric cars won’t’ happen!)
44/ They refuse to accept the future once they understand it
43/ An inability to accept the future even if they understand it
42/ They don’t even try to understand the future
41/ They don’t understand the future
40/ They are conflicted, in that they share these traits:

39/ What has changed is the audience and a certain belief that a mindset of anger would be enough to take a region into the future. I’ve spent a lot of time thinking about these people – and the mindset that drives them.
38/ Back to my session evaluations: what I’ve come to learn is that it was not anything I was doing on stage – my style, extensive content, and customization had not changed much.
36/ There’s no need for hard work, they think; no requirement for skills upgrading; no demand to do the difficult effort at reinventing. If they simply ignore the future … it will go away.
35/ They’ve tuned out, carefully constructing their own magical, fictional future; they create their own false reality because it makes it easier for them to avoid the real reality.
34/ And so here we are today – as a futurist, it is painfully obvious that a large cross-section of the populace simply has no interest in understanding the future.
33/ …started to frame this thinking by diplomatically addressing it through a Jetsons/Flinstones analogy.

32/ Over time, I noticed that this type of negative thinking about the future seemed to fill more and more of my audience makeup – people who simply didn’t like a story involving the reality of the future, disruptive trends, and the era of exponential acceleration.[... I…
31/ …investments….simplistic solutions are lousy bandaids – when you seek the easy way out, the real road to recovery takes hard work!”

30/ Here’s a fun comment I wrote when I shared this video some years back: “Many manufacturing companies, while currently enjoying success, are going to find it difficult to make their way out of it because they didn’t do what needed to be done in terms of skills…
29/ Hard work, major investments, time, and patience.

28/ Check the video as to what I spoke about at another manufacturing event right around the same time. It’s all about the importance of skills and knowledge in the sector as new materials, methodologies and complexities come into the industry.

27/ Months later, the world would change as people came to cling to the belief that it was by ranting, screaming, yelling, and generally becoming that boorish neighbor that no one ever invited to neighborhood parties was a pathway to success. Gosh, we tired quickly.

Reality?
26/ …just-build-a-wall-and-make-things-great-again type of thinking.

25/ Looking back to my event 5 years ago today, at a major manufacturing conference, it’s pretty obvious that my audience was starting to consume the drug that promised the buzz of the ‘the easy way out,‘ the elixir of a simple-minded…
24/ In fact, it takes a heck of a lot of hard work. But when people are being conned, they tend to ignore the reality of this advice. That’s what was happening with my audiences.

22/ Hey, have you seen the headlines? Did you notice a few months ago that the initiative has died? The Foxconn con is over, as is much of the great-again type of thinking except for some remaining feeble-minded holdouts.
21/ Expect to wake up in 5 years to headlines as to how idiotic the structure of the deal was. Don’t jump on board fake trends."

20/ Check what I had to say in point #5: https://t.co/BtNK01WodY
[...

"Don’t be dumb.  can’t think of a dumber economic initiative than the money that Wisconsin is putting behind the Foxconn plant.

19/ …in the middle of America. I immediately called it a fraud, as captured just a few months later in a post, “The Story Behind the Picture: 20 Big Rules for Economic Development in the Era of Acceleration!”

18/ Just one year later, the world was in a very strange place, and a con job was being pulled upon the populace in this region with the announcement of the Foxconn Wisconsin factory – a magical, $10 billion investment by a Chinese company to manufacture advanced LED screens…
17/ The expectation of how to get to the future was shifting; magic wand thinking was taking hold.

16/ I remember thinking to myself:

“They’ve been sold the idea that a magic wand can be waved, and things will be great again. Except, the future doesn’t happen like that!”

What was going on?
15/ The audience seemed to want nothing to do with this. I remember looking out at them, and thinking to myself – they’re not listening.
13/ You know, the typical grab back of disruptive trends.
12/ …products and the impact this would have on manufacturing skills.

11/ …Industrial-Internet-of-Things and process reinvention, the rapid arrival of new, lightweight manufacturing materials, the necessity for the rapid and continual reinvention of products in the face of faster product obsolescence, the arrival of hyper-connected, intelligent…

10/ My keynote covered the usual range of high-velocity trends providing opportunity and challenge within the sector – 3D printing and additive manufacturing, the acceleration of robotics, the arrival of augmented reality (such as for quality inspection), the…

9/ I really noticed this issue at first with a manufacturing conference I spoke at in Minneapolis, in October 2016, in front of a broad cross-section of mid-level manufacturing executives and engineers from throughout the Midwest.

8/ I’ve still been bang on with the trends; my stage style rocks; the people who want to align to the future listen carefully and act accordingly. But others simply …. tune out. And that number was increasing. Why was this so? Keep reading!

7/ Folks who didn’t like my message, the trends I covered, or the manner in which I presented it.

For a time, I worried about this. And then, I realized – it wasn’t about me. It was them.

6/ And then, around 2016, I noticed a shift, which was obviously closely aligned to the new political volatility — I started to notice an upward trend in the negative type of comment on the evaluations.

5/ I guess I can’t really have been successful this long if it hasn’t been mostly positive and laudatory. But even so, I’ve always taken the few negative comments to mind as a means of doing better the next time, an opportunity to move forward.
4/ It’s a mixture of the positive and negative, the glowing and the mediocre, and the occasional burst of outright hostility or wildly enthusiastic “you-changed-my-life-for-the-better” gushiness.

3/ That’s a lot of insight shared!

A guy like me lives and dies on the session evaluations, the after-keynote comments, the follow-up tweets or e-mails, and other feedback.

2/ Over the last 28 years, I’ve appeared on stage worldwide at well over 2,000 events, in front of upwards of 2 million people. There have been small events of a few dozen, and many large-scale Las Vegas and other conference center events with 5,000 or 7,500 people.

18/ *** Embrace the uncertainty. It’s here, it’s everywhere, and it’s not going away. Accept it, and let it motivate you rather than detract you.
17/ *** Think longer term.  This too shall pass. Everything you do today might have a return tomorrow, even if we have no idea what that might be. Because – what’s the alternative?
16/ *** Modify more.  See ‘vague plan.’ If you had the planning wrong, adjust the plan. What will I be doing online a month from now? Heck, I don’t know. I’ll know when I get there!
15/ I discovered an online community on Facebook for the software I am using – Ecamm Live – and for me, it is now like drinking from a video production firehose!
14/ *** Collaborate more.  See ‘learn as you go.’ The global hive mind is your new best friend. Learn how to harness its riches.

12/ *** Work the criticism.  When you get it wrong, take the lumps. Listen to the critics. Learn from what they tell you. My 2nd broadcast was a dog’s breakfast mess, and someone took the time to tell me so. It hurt at first – but then I took it as an opportunity to do better.
11/ *** Go for the small wins. This is not about excellence. This is about achievement.

10/ *** Make mistakes. Don’t be scared. Make mistakes. Learn from them. Repeat. I committed to going live online even though I wasn’t certain it might not work. Some things blew up along the way, but it wasn’t totally awful. Just a bit awful. That’s ok.
9/ *** Be hungry for learning. My thirst for new knowledge is at an all-time high.

8/ *** Learn as you go. You are an expert at nothing in this new world and an amateur at everything. Just-in-time knowledge has long been my key skills watchword. It’s now a reality. I know WAY MORE today than I knew a month ago, and I will know more next month than I do today.
7/ *** Speed matters more than a plan ***, more so than ever before. I had no idea what my real goal was with an online broadcast – I keep figuring that out as I go.
6/ *** Keep your plan vague: don’t overdo it. The old world had us in long, luxurious planning cycles. That’s gone – both the time horizon and the certainty of the plan.
5/ Reflecting, these are the lessons I’ve learned as I thought about my own voyage in the last two months:

4/ My mindset is found in this quote from a stage from my earlier life.

I’ve always believed that we should often make the effort to move forward despite uncertainty – action is better than inaction.

My journey echoes the journey of the other action-pioneers I see out there.
2/ In March 2020, I hit the ground running – the world was shutting down, my business speaking on stage collapsed, and I needed a plan.

1/ What did you learn during the pandemic? Did you capitalize on your speed? Are you prepared to use those lessons as a foundation for going forward?

26/ Do.

25/ Don’t.
24/ Don’t be boxed in.
23/ Don’t be small.
22/ Don’t be negative.
21/ Don’t limit your dreams.
20/ Don’t hold yourself back.
19/ Don’t think it can’t be done.
18/ Don’t listen to the naysayers.
17/ What did I learn along the way?
16/ Since then, I've carved out a career as a 'futurist,' advising organizations like NASA, Disney, the World Bank, Pfizer. My client list is killer.
14/ When the Internet finally exploded into public consciousness around 1993, I had already been ‘online’ for 11 years.
13/ I kept on my path of discovery and my voyage of curiosity.
12/ I don’t think I listened to them.
11/ While working on this, I was told I was throwing away a ‘perfectly good career’ in finance, and that I should be more cautious with my reckless ambitions.
10/ I came up with a business-networking idea that I called LinkAge, 25 years before LinkedIn appears on the scene.

9/ I explored the boundaries of possibility and helped to launch some initiatives that were way ahead of their time. 

I believed that global online connectivity would change the world, and I wanted to be part of it. Collaborative thinking?
8/ I found myself becoming immersed in the world of technology and the opportunities of technology.
7/ (Hint: look up 300-baud).

6/ 40 years ago, I signed into the online world for the very first time. I had a career path and trajectory in the world of finance, but I was intrigued, overwhelmed, and stunned by the potential world that might be found at the end of a 300-baud online connection.

5/ These are people to avoid.

They live a life of negativity, viewing everything through a lens of impossible challenges, while you see the world through a filter of opportunity.

I've lived exactly through this situation.
4/ We are all surrounded by those who want to kill our innovative ideas, crush our dreams, or hold us back from pursuing our potential.

3/ You will have a great idea. They will pounce on it, and tell you that it will fail. That it won’t work. It’s a dumb idea. It’s doomed to fail. You should be doing something better with your time.

Ignore them. Pursue your belief, and live your life.

45/ Here’s a video clip where I’m covering the Masters in Businss Imagination on stage! https://t.co/cVJXbxT8Rh
44/ Over the last 15 years, a number of organizations have had me frame creativity & innovation in the context of an MBI Keynote - learn more at https://t.co/kVOedC9Oge
43/ The full Manifesto is at https://t.co/97BOldAtSF

42/ The MBI Manifesto is a call to action – a call to creativity – and a call for imagination.

Pursue the MBI, and you will rediscover a world in which change and challenge is turned in to opportunity and success.

41/ Pursue Your MBA!

An MBI is the most important degree program for any executive for the future.

Although the degree isn’t yet enshrined in any university curriculum – it doesn’t even show up in a Google search! – it is clearly what every executive must possess.
40/ If they don’t have what is needed to make it work, they look for creative and imaginative ways to get around that limitation.

39/ MBI’s don’t say “it won’t work.” Instead, they ask the question, “how can we make it work? 

MBI’s refuse to accept failure as an option, and instead, constantly work to ensure that goals are achieved.

38/ The result is that they are eager to have any idea assessed, analyzed and challenged.

They encourage debate, knowing that it is through such a process that a simple idea can be turned into a “great idea.

37/ MBI’s live for the opportunity to have ideas challenged and debated. 

MBI’s truly understand that their own bias, developed through years of experience, can often blind them to real opportunity.

36/ Examine the make up of a team assembled by an MBI, and you will find a group of people who are all very different. That’s because an MBI knows that a multitude of difference can bring far more creative thinking than the sameness from a group of clones.
35/ The result is that they are constantly on the prowl for new ideas and new ways of thinking, and understand that often this can come from those who think differently than they do.

34/ MBI’s embrace diverse thinking.

They listen to people who are different then them. An effective MBI knows that the attitudes that they possess can restrict them in their thinking, and that the knowledge they know is but a sliver of what there is to know.

33/ MBI’s embrace change rather than shying away from it. 

MBI’s relish the idea of change, for it is the oxygen that fuels their fire every day.

32/ Their passion as leaders is such that their enthusiasm becomes infectious; the most successful to such a degree that they begin to steer the entire organization towards their fresh and exciting way of thinking.

31/ Not MBI’s : they approach each day as a new and exciting opportunity! They know that the world is wide open for them to use their way of thinking differently to shake things up, discover opportunity, and redefine parameters.

30/ MBI’s accept challenges with passion and enthusiasm. 

Most studies continue to show that many people go to work each with dread, fear and worry being their constant companion. Once they arrive, they fall into a monotonous routine of meetings, checklists and to-do’s.
29/ They know that barrier’s, perceived or otherwise, are simply temporary roadblocks that they can get around with fresh insight, imaginative analysis, and creative thinking.

28/ MBI’s refuse to say the word “can’t”. 

MBI’s refuse to accept the limitations that might have been placed upon them.
27/ Rather than viewing this as a burden to be assumed, they view the opportunity to continuously learn something new with passion and enthusiasm.

26/ They don’t make the dangerous assumption that what they know will carry them in to tomorrow; they realize that the knowledge and skills that they will need to do their job in the future will require skills that are infinitely more complex.

25/ MBI’s have the skill to learn and unlearn.

MBI’s know that we live in a world in which learning has become their job, and just-in-time knowledge has become the foundation for future success.
24/ They provide forward oriented goals and objectives that are framed around the change that surrounds them, and use this as the fuel to spur their team on to achievement

23/ …excel.\...\MBI’s have the ability to bring ideas to life. 

MBI’s motivate people to excel by helping them to get over their own concern and worry about the future. They paint a picture of where the organization is going to go, and what it is going to take to get there.

22/ Such stale thinking doesn’t drive the passion of an MBI: instead, they look at the world around them, and constantly question how they might shake things up a bit, not simply to cause change, but in order to provide a climate in which the people within it can succeed and…

21/ MBI’s refuse to accept the status quo. 

Ogden Nash once observed that “progress is great, but it has gone on far too long.”
20/ They regularlyy scan for signs of disruptive threat, and rather than viewing it as something to be feared, ask themselves: “where is the potential here?”
19/ With this being the foundation of their attitude, they have come to learn that their focus must continuously examine how to capitalize on change, in order to turn it into opportunity.

18/ MBI’s focus on opportunity, not threat. 

MBI’s realize that in the absence of action, continuous disruptive change inevitably has negative consequences.

17/ In doing so, they can shake a team out of its administrative complacency, and motivate them into a mode in which they are able to rethink, redo and re-imagine, such that they lend much more value to the organization.

16/ MBI’s spur creativity in other people. 

An MBI possesses a unique and critical skill: they can spur others around them to develop similar levels of imaginative thinking.
15/ These lenses help them to generate new ideas, come up with imaginative solutions, and think creatively on a continuous basis
14/ They are willing to abandon any attitudes which might cause them to believe that everything is going to stay the same, with the result that they view the world through a different set of lenses.
13/ They know that the foundation of everything around them is shifting and twisting, and that it is in such movement that the future is being defined.
11/ Here is my call to action! It is time that progressive, future oriented leaders focus on developing their skills such that they can be honored with the title: Masters of Business Imagination!

10/ The result is that they continue to wake up each morning and think, “what happened to the world I knew?” Perhaps that is because their focus has been misdirected – they’ve become experts in “administration” at a time when what they really need is a lot more “imagination.”

9/ Without such insight, they have no idea as to what they must do in order to thrive in an era of rapid change.

Worse yet, they focus on managing, rather than leading. Administering, rather than inspiring. Complying, rather than creating.

8/ Most people don’t have such a capability; indeed, I’ve come to believe that most people continue to stumble and meander their way into the future, without any firm grasp of how their skills, industry, knowledge or industry is evolving.

6/ How can you keep operating the way you do – with the same culture, structure, rules and methodologies, when the rate of change that envelopes your organization is so dramatic and so darned fast?

We live in an era of unprecedented and relentless change.

5/ It needs more MBI’s – Masters of Business Imagination!

Clearly you need different skills to take you into a future that is becoming far more complex, challenging and different by the minute.

4/ Figuratively and literally, it is time to move beyond the thinking that has led us to a world of MBA’s – Masters of Business Administration – and focus upon the critical skill that will take you into tomorrow.

The world doesn’t need more administrators.

3/ It’s time to abandon the thinking that has had you anchored firmly to the past – and to shift your focus to the future, with enthusiasm, motivation and imagination.

You can do this by abandoning any pretence that the skills of yesterday will be important tomorrow.
2/ Complacency in a time of rapid, disruptive change can be a death sentence – not only for organizations, but for the careers and skills of those who work there!

1/ The Masters in Business Imagination Manifesto

The world doesn’t need more administrators. It needs more MBI’s – people with a Masters of Business Imagination!
